question: Gif mon his mete etan (willan) #### — If someone does not want to eat his foot
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the negated third person singular present form 'nyle' because the subject is 'mon'

question: Seo cwen urum wordum and gewritum hieran (willan) #### — The queen does not want to hear our words and writings
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the negated third person singular present form 'nyle' because the subject is 'seo cwen'

question: Ðu (willan) #### to minum gode þe gebiddan — You do not want to worship my gods
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the negated second person singular present form 'nylt' because the subject is 'Ðu'

question: Ic wæs on cearcerne, and ge min (willan) #### fandian — I was incarcerated, and ye didn't want to find me
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the negated plural past form 'noldon' because the subject is 'ge'

question: Seo fæmne (willan) #### him andswarigen nan word — The woman did not want to answer him with any words
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the negated third person singular past form 'nolde' because the subject is 'Seo fæmne'

question: Hie hine heton þæt flæsc etan and he hit etan (willan) #### — They ordered him to eat that flesh, and he didn't want to eat it
explanation: Here 'willan' is in the negated third person singular past form 'nolde' because the subject is 'he'

question: He (habban) #### nænige stowe, þæt he mihte to gan — He didn't have any place that he could go to
explanation: Here 'habban' is in the negated third person singular past form 'næfde' because the subject is 'He'

question: Ða men þa þe on woh lifiaþ, (habban) #### hie na Crist on heora heortan — Those men who live in wickedness do not have Christ in their hearts
explanation: Here 'habban' is in the negated plural present form 'nabbaþ' because the subject is 'Ða men'

question: Ðæt gast (habban) #### flæsc ond ban — The ghost does not have flesh and bone
explanation: Here 'habban' is in the negated third person singular present form 'næfþ' because the subject is 'Ðæt gast'

question: Hie win (habban) #### — They did not have wine
explanation: Here 'habban' is in the negated plural past form 'næfdon' because the subject is 'Hie'

question: Hwæt hæfst ðu, gif ðu me (habban) ####? — What do you have, if you don't have me?
explanation: Here 'habban' is in the negated second person singular present form 'næfst' because the subject is 'ðu'

question: Ic (wesan) #### freoh — I am not free
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated first person singular present form 'neom' because the subject is 'Ic'

question: Ðu (wesan) #### dysig, ac þin bearn is dysig — You aren't foolish, but your child is foolish
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated second person singular present form 'neart' because the subject is 'Ðu'

question: Se monandæg (wesan) #### na fyrmest daga on þære wucan: ac is se oþer — Monday is not the first day in the week, but it is the second
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated third person singular present form 'nis' because the subject is 'monandæg'

question: Hit (wesan) #### alyfed! — It is not allowed!
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated third person singular present form 'nis' because the subject is 'Hit'

question: Ðæt næfre nan man to nanum deofulgilde ne gebidde, (wesan) #### to nanum deadum stane ne to nanum dumbum treowe — That no man ever pray to any devil image, nor to any dead stone, nor to any dumb tree
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated third person singular present form 'nis' because the subject is 'man'

question: (wesan) #### nan ðing wyrse, ðonne druncenscipe — There is nothing worse than drunkeness
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated third person singular present form 'nis' because the subject is 'nan ðing'

question: Wære ðu todæg on huntnoþe? Ic (wesan) #### — Were you hunting today? I was not
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated first person singular past form 'næs' because the subject is 'ic'

question: Hie wiscaþ ðæt hie næfre (wesan) #### acennede — They wished that they had never been born
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated plural past form 'næron' because the subject is 'hie'

question: Eall þes middaneard (wesan) #### þe mare dryges landes — In all this middle earth there was not a drier land
explanation: Here 'wesan' is in the negated third person singular past form 'næs'
